To  help  achieve  health-related  MDGs  of  the  Philippines,  the  Project 
will  address  low  and  inefficient  public  expenditures  in  health  care  by 
mobilizing additional off-budget credit for pro-poor investment through 
a  government  financial  intermediary,  leveraging  private  participation, 
and improving allocation toward investment priorities. These priorities 
include  (i)  maternal  and  child  health  services,  (ii)  control  of 
communicable  diseases,  (iii) services  to  improve  access  to  basic 
health  care,  and  (iv) referral  services  including  laboratory  and  other 
diagnostic services.   
 
The  Project  will  support  DBP’s  Sustainable  Health  Care  Investment 
Program,  a  credit  facility  established  in  2007  to  support  the  health 
sector  reform  agenda  and  implementation  framework—Fourmula 
One for Health (F1)—of the Department of Health (DOH). The credit 
facility is available to local government units (LGUs), and the private 
sector  through  two  windows  (i)  direct  retail  lending  for  LGUs  and 
larger  private  sector  subborrowers,  and  (ii)  wholesale  lending  to 
accredited financial intermediaries (microfinance intermediaries, rural 
and  thrift  banks)  for  small  private  subborrowers.  The  Investment 
Program  is  financed  from  DBP’s  own  resources  and  supplementary 
funds  of  development  partners,  and  supports  both  capital 
investments and working capital. 
 
The Project’s outputs are (i) upgraded LGU health services, (ii) more 
efficient  health  delivery  systems  through  public–private  partnership 
(PPP)  and  innovative  strategies,  (iii)  improved  access  to  small-scale 
private  providers,  and  (iv)  enhanced  institutional  capacity  for  health 
sector lending. 
 
The Government of the Philippines (the Government) is committed to 
meeting the country's MDGs. The Philippines MDG Report for 2007 
highlights the mixed achievements, and especially the slow progress 
in  reducing  maternal  mortality,  and  the  need  for  better  health 
services.

ADB’s  Health  Sector  Development  Program  (2004–2010)  supported

policy dialogue on health sector development. 
 
The  Project  will  address  a  key  bottleneck  in  the  implementation  of 
DOH’s F1 by providing credit to upgrade health facilities. This will not 
only improve health services, but will trigger higher reimbursement of 
the  Philippine  Health  Insurance  Corporation  (PHIC)  and  thereby 
reduce  the  cost  of  health  care  for  the  poor,  which  in  turn  will 
contribute to achieving MDGs.  
 
The impact of the Project is improved overall health status, especially 
in relation to MDGs by (i) reduced under-five child mortality rate and 
reduced  infant  mortality  rate  (MDG  4),  and  (ii) reduced  maternal 
mortality  ratio  (MDG  5).  The  Project’s  outcome  is  increased  use  of 
basic health care and referral services by the poor in general, and by 
women and children in particular, in the subproject sites. The Project 
will be nationwide, with the exception of the National Capital Region. 
 
The project investment cost is estimated at $63.36 million equivalent, 
including taxes and duties of $5.50 million equivalent.

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
The  Government  of  the  Philippines,  with  its  partners,  wants  to  improve  health  care  for  its 
population of about 90 million to achieve the Millennium Development  Goals (MDGs)  and ensure 
timely and adequate response to the changing morbidity patterns in the Philippines. The country’s 
MDG performance is mixed: the infant mortality rate was reportedly reduced to 24 deaths per 1,000 
live births in 2006 and is on track. The malnutrition rate (weight by age) shows little improvement at 
26% but is above the regional average. The maternal mortality ratio has declined to 162 deaths per 
100,000 live births in 2006, and it may not reach MDG targets. Tuberculosis and other communicable 
diseases  remain  common,  and  HIV/AIDS  is  emerging.2 Health  indicators  in  the  Eastern  Visayas, 
Bicol,  and  most  of  Mindanao  are  particularly  lagging.  The  country’s  relatively  slow  progress  in 
health is linked to poverty, rapid population growth, and low investment in health. Health services 
fall short in terms of access and affordability for the poor, quality and efficiency of service delivery, 
and financing of services and investment.  
 
3. 
The  Philippines  has  an  average  per  capita  income  of  $1,351,  albeit  with  considerable 
inequity. Economic growth was 7% in 2007 but slowed to 4.6% annually in the first half of 2008. It 
is predicted to slow further to 3%–4% in 2009. Reflecting the global slowdown, exports have fallen 
and  so  has  foreign  direct  investment.  Public  sector  consumption  and  investment  spending  have 
contracted  in  real  terms,  and  private  sector  consumption  growth  is  at  its  lowest  since  2001. 
Inflation  was  a  high  7%  in  2008  and  is  rising.  It  particularly  affects  the  poor,  given  the  high  food 
price  inflation.  The  Government  has  responded  by  postponing  its  goal  of  a  balanced  budget  to 
allow for increased spending in 2008 in infrastructure, social protection, and subsidies.  
 
4. 
The  robust  economic  growth  in  recent  years  has  apparently  had  little  impact  on  poverty. 
The 2006 poverty level of 33%, or 27.6 million, is similar to the 2000 level. Income inflation is not 
keeping pace with price inflation, especially in recent times. Social safety net programs are limited, 
giving  the  poor  and  near  poor  little  protection.  Catastrophic  events  such  as  the  loss  of  a  job  or 
hospitalization  result  in  food  shortages  among  the  poor,  and  cause  the  near  poor  to  slip  into 
poverty.  In  1997,  a  sponsored  program  for  the  poor  was  introduced  under  the  Philippine  Health 
Insurance Corporation (PHIC) to offset some health care costs, and in 2007, the Ahon Pamilyang 
Pilipino  (conditional  cash  transfer  program)  was  piloted.  To  improve  social  protection,  the  PHIC 
aims  to  achieve  universal  enrollment  of  the  poor,  with  budgetary  support  from  central  and  local 
governments, and to provide a comprehensive benefits package for the poor.  
 
5. 
Health sector spending remains low. In 2005, it was 3.3% of gross domestic product or $40 
per capita. While public expenditures for health have grown in absolute terms, they have not kept 
pace  with  population  and  inflationary  pressures.  Health  care  is  financed  from  multiple  sources,

6. 
To  help  improve  health  services,  the  Government  is  encouraging  local  government  units 
(LGUs)  to  mobilize  off-budget  support  through  government  financial  intermediaries  (GFIs),  the 
private  sector,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and  civil  society,  with  special  schemes  for 
poorer  LGUs  and  those  unable  to  access  funds  from  the  private  capital  markets.  The 
Government’s LGU financing framework (1996) is helping create a credit culture among LGUs to 
improve their creditworthiness. Its LGU credit policy framework (1996) promotes the involvement of 
GFIs in LGU financing, and it guides GFIs and the Municipal Development Fund Office (MDFO) to 
act as catalysts to bring LGUs into the mainstream of private capital markets. This will open up off-
budget financing channels for health investment.  
 
7. 
The Project will support DBP to offer LGUs and the private sector better access to credit to 
help  achieve  MDGs,  improve  public  sector  management,  stimulate  public–private  partnership 
(PPP), and improve rural access to health care. The Project is included in the country operations 
business plan for 2009–20103 and is in line with the Asian Development Bank's (ADB’s) long-term 
strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020).4   
 
B. 
 
 
 
8. 
The Philippines has a dual health care system of largely tax-financed public health services 
at  national and  local levels  plus  an  extensive  for-profit  and  nonprofit  private  sector  that  is  largely 
financed from user fees. Public health services in the Philippines are provided by the Department 
of  Health  (DOH),  LGUs,  and  other  agencies.  LGUs  finance  and  operate  provincial  and  district

private health sector includes clinics, hospitals, insurance companies, manufacturers of drugs and 
equipment,  and  training  institutes. 6  PHIC  is  a  government-owned  and  controlled  corporation 
attached  to  DOH,  mandated  to  administer  the  PHIC  program  and  ensure  that  Filipinos  have 
financial access to health services. 
 
9. 
The  Philippines  health  system  has  gone  through  several  reforms,  including  devolution  of 
health services to local government units in 1991 and the national health insurance act in 1995 that 
included the nonformal sector. In 1999, DOH launched the health sector reform agenda to improve 
the sector’s delivery, regulation, and financing. In 2005, DOH launched Fourmula One for Health 
(F1)—the  reform’s  implementation  framework  for  2005–2010.  F1  is  directed  toward  achieving 
better  health  outcomes,  a  more  responsive  health  system,  and  more  equitable  health  care 
financing (especially for the poor). Its four objectives are to (i) secure more, better, and sustained 
financing for health care; (ii) assure the quality and affordability of health goods and services; (iii) 
ensure  access  to  and  availability  of  essential  and  basic  health  care  packages;  and  (iv)  improve 
performance  of  the  health  system.  F1  is  designed  to  implement  critical  health  interventions  as  a 
single  package,  backed  by  effective  management  infrastructure  and  financing  arrangements.  It 
engages the entire health sector, including public and private services, development partners, and 
civil  society,  and  it  is  the  basis  for  DOH’s  medium-term  expenditure  framework  (2007–2010).  It

2. 

Access and Affordability  

 
Demand for health services remains low among the poor and vulnerable groups.8 This may be 
12. 
due to a variety of reasons, including (i) the relatively high cost of medical care, drugs and transport; 
(ii) social  and  cultural  biases  of  both  patients  and  providers;  (iii)  lack  of  understanding  of  modern 
medical care; and (iv) limited geographical access to services. Households have limited information on 
health benefits and costs, and they may be reluctant to use services due to the perceived poor quality 
or high cost of care. Only 37% of users of public hospitals were satisfied with public health services 
(footnote 8). Facility-based childbirth remains low among the poor (11% among the poor, versus 38% 
overall in 2003). Child immunization coverage is also lower (55% among the poor, versus 70% overall 
in  2003).  The  poor  primarily  use  the  barangay  health  stations  or  rural  health  units  for  health  care 
because of access and affordability considerations (79%). When possible, however, lower level care 
is bypassed for higher-level care even when not needed, contributing to low occupancy rates (20%–
40%)  in  district  hospitals  and  overuse  of  provincial  hospitals.  System  reforms  and  investments  for 
upgrading are required that will redistribute demand by appropriate levels of care.  
 
13. 
The cost of health care, including for drugs, is a key reason for the low utilization by the poor. 
Estimates suggest that about 30%–40% of the population finds it difficult to pay for drugs.9 Financial 
protection  against  illness  costs  has  been  one  of  the  Government’s  top  priorities.  A  social  health 
insurance  program—PHIC—was  established  in  1995  with  the  mandate  to  provide  financial 
protection against illness costs. A decade later, coverage is still not universal and is extremely low 
among the informal sectors and the poor (50% among the poor, versus 73% overall in 2007).10 The

Quality and Efficiency 

 
16. 
The public sector has an expanded network of services reaching down to the village level. 
Since  devolution,  however,  the  health  delivery  system  faces  fragmented  organization  and 
management,  delivery,  and  financing,  which  appear  to  favor  investments  in  urban  hospitals. 12 
Supply and distribution of public goods and services, such as vaccinations against communicable 
diseases,  essential  drugs,  and  family  planning  commodities,  remain  insufficient. 13 Basic  health

resulting  in  patients’  inability  to  use  services  or  self-referring  to  hospitals  unnecessarily.  The 
Philippines produces a large number of doctors and nurses, but the increasing export of medical 
personnel for overseas employment has resulted in staff shortages and quality constraints. Further, 
basic health services are not linked to appropriate referral services, making it difficult, for example, 
to address childbirth complications.

use of hospitals for basic health services, long waiting lines, high-costs incurred by patients due to

hospitals lack trained hospital managers and are not financially sustainable. Further, public hospitals

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

Expected Benefits and Impacts 

 
A.  
 
92. 
Health  Benefits.  The  Project  is  designed  to  address  MDGs  by  targeting  the  poor,  in 
particular  women  and  children  with  poor  health  indicators.  It  specifically  addresses  gaps  in  basic 
health  care,  including  maternal  and  child  health  care,  communicable  disease  control,  diagnostic 
services, and referral services. The Project promotes the use of PHIC-accredited health facilities, 
thereby  promoting  quality  standards  of  services,  and  it  supports  partnership  between  the  public 
and private sectors to address gaps in health care, such as staff shortages for maternal care.  
 
93. 
Social,  Gender,  and  Poverty  Benefits. The Project is designed to result in major social, 
gender, and poverty benefits with multiple impacts. A larger proportion of the beneficiaries will be 
the poor, women, and children. They will benefit from upgrading LGU health facilities and also from 
filling gaps in service delivery through PPP and support for small providers close to communities. 
Oversight  arrangements,  capacity  development,  provincial  plans,  eligibility  criteria,  and  targeted 
funding for assisting small providers will help to ensure that suitable subprojects are selected that 
yield maximum benefit for these vulnerable groups. The Project also supports PHIC accreditation 
of  health  providers  close  to  the  underserved  population.  Finally,  the  Project  provides  improved 
access to credit and opportunities for improved earnings for small-scale health providers, who are 
often female (midwives, drug store owners). The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is 
in Appendix 13, and the gender and development action plan is in Appendix 14. 
 
94. 
Financial Protection of the Poor. The poor will benefit (i) through reduced costs for care 
and  transport,  plus  greater  opportunity  to  receive  care,  as  facilities  become  more  accessible;  (ii) 
from increased subsidy from PHIC-accredited health facilities, including generic drug outlets, and 
(iii) indirectly, through better health resulting in less income erosion and increased productivity. 
 
95. 
Economic Benefits. The subprojects will address (i) externalities, such as through primary 
health care; (ii) merit goods, such as through direct impact on woman and child health, reduction in 
unnecessary use of hospitals, and better information to consumers; (iii) uncertainty, such as due to 
complications during childbirth; and (iv) inequity in access. The Project will promote both technical 
(e.g.,  access  to  affordable  generic  drugs)  and  allocative  (e.g.,  access  to  cost-effective 
interventions) efficiencies. It is expected to have a significant impact on the poor, particularly women 
and  children.  A  cost-effectiveness  analysis  was  undertaken  on  two  subgroups  (i)  infants  and 
particularly neonates; and (ii) women of childbearing age, particularly those who are pregnant. The 
assumption  is  that  as  access  to  credit  increases,  and  health  care  providers  are  accredited,  more 
women  will  deliver  under  health  care  providers.  This  will  result  in  healthier  women  and  newborns. 
The  Project  could  therefore  essentially bring  down  maternal and neonatal deaths in the subproject 
sites. While the analysis focuses on infant and maternal deaths, many of these interventions should 
also  reduce  infant  and  maternal  distress  and  morbidity.  Consequently,  total  health  benefits,  as 
measured  by  a  composite  measure  such  as  disability-adjusted  life  years,  would  be  significantly 
greater.  In  the  15th  year  from  the  start  of  the  investment,  the  Project  will  maximize  net  benefits 
accruing  to  the  country  (positive  net  present  value)  and  the  internal  rate  of  return  will  surpass  the 
discount rate. An economic and financial sustainability analysis is in Supplementary Appendix G.

Assumptions, Risks, and Mitigating Measures 

96. 
Financial  Sustainability. Analyses were undertaken to assess the financial sustainability of 
subprojects, and these were broken down to (i) retail lending subprojects, and (ii) wholesale lending 
subprojects.  An  actual  case  of  a  LGU  provincial  hospital  expansion  was  taken  from  one  province. 
Additionally,  for  wholesale  lending,  actual  costs  and  estimated  incomes  were  considered  for  small-
scale health providers, such as midwives, obstetricians, and drug stores. The financial sustainability 
analysis was determined by using weighted average cost of capital and financial internal rate of return 
estimates  for  each  subproject,  and  composite  financial  internal  rate  of  return  for  the  Project.  The 
analysis suggests that the Project is generally financially sustainable. However, LGU hospitals, which 
are not income-generating entities and generally rely on LGUs cross-subsidization, under the current 
budget scenario are dependent on PHIC reimbursements for sustained operation expenditures. There 
is risk of increase in balance billing, as hospitals may try to increase user fees (charged to patients) in 
response  to  their  increased  capital  investment.  The  subprojects  will  mitigate  this  risk  by  contracting 
with PHIC, which stipulates hospital charges for its beneficiaries. Most small-scale subprojects were 
financially  sustainable,  although  the  sensitivity  analysis  suggests  that  they  could  be  vulnerable  if 
revenue generation is delayed.  
 
B.  
 
97. 
Key  assumptions  for  successful  implementation  are  (i)  adequate  recurrent  and  capital 
budgets by Government and LGUs for health-related programs, (ii) enrollment of indigents and the 
poor  into  PHIC,  (iii)  provider  access  to  a  comprehensive  PHIC  benefits  and  reimbursements 
package, and (iv) LGUs and private health entrepreneurs are willing and able to borrow at DBP’s 
(or financial intermediaries’) terms. Some risks and mitigating measures are given below. 
 
98. 
Delayed Implementation of F1. To date, DOH has mobilized 37 out of the 78 provinces to 
achieve F1 and it plans to cover all by 2010. If the mobilization of LGUs or the preparation of LGU 
investments  is  delayed,  project  disbursement  will  be  delayed.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  DBP,  in 
partnership  with  DOH  and  DILG,  will  need  to  ensure  the  timely  mobilization  of  LGUs  and 
preparation of the subproject feasibility studies.   
 
99. 
Limited Experience in the Health Sector. While DBP has established a new credit facility 
for health development projects, it has limited experience in the health sector. Its experience has 
primarily been in large-scale private projects, where it was not necessary to provide TA or whose 
performance  could  easily  be  monitored.  DBP  is  well-versed  with  financial  management  and 
assessing  creditworthiness.  DBP  will  also  need  to  market  its  new  lending  product  to  generate 
demand among LGU and small-scale subborrowers. DBP will obtain expertise in the health sector 
and  form  partnerships  with  other  key  agencies—DOH  and  MDFO  in  particular.  Under  the  LGU 
credit policy framework, DBP and MDFO form an alliance in lending to LGUs.

HEALTH SECTOR ANALYSIS   

The Sector 

 
A. 
 
The Government of the Philippines and its partners need to close the gap in access to 
1. 
health  care,  especially  for  the  poor  and  for  those  in  the  rural  areas,  in  order  to  achieve  the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and ensure timely and adequate response to changing 
morbidity  patterns  in  the  country.  This  appendix  summarizes  the  sector,  what  can  be  done  to 
close the gap, and the role of the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP).  
 
2. 
Filipinos’  life  expectancy  at  birth  is  71  years  (2005)  on  average,  but  remote  provinces 
have  much  lower  life  expectancies. 1 The  country  has  a  mixed  status  on  the  health-related 
MDGs. The Philippines National Statistics Office reports that the infant mortality rate (IMR) had 
steadily  declined  to  31  infant  deaths  per  1,000  live  births  by  2004,  and  the  maternal  mortality 
ratio (MMR) was at 200 per 100,000 live births in 2000 and 108 in 2003. Both IMR and MMR 
are higher in the Visayas and Mindanao compared to Luzon. The MMR is much higher in Bicol, 
Leyte,  and  Samar.  Maternal  and  child  deaths  in  remote  areas  are  likely  to  be  underreported. 
The  IMR  for  children  whose  mothers  have  no  education  is  65  deaths  per  1,000  live  births 
compared  with  15  deaths  per  1,000  live  births  for  children  whose  mothers  have  college  or 
higher education. Although the MMR also shows major disparities by income status, it remains 
relatively high, too, among the more affluent, thus demonstrating that this is not just a matter of 
access and affordability but also one of quality of care.   
 
3. 
Noncommunicable  diseases  (like  asthma,  heart  diseases,  hypertension,  and  cancers) 
have  been  increasing,  causing  early  morbidity,  disability,  and  mortality  as  well  as  a  drain  on 
health  care  resources.  Long  existent  and  treatable  infectious  diseases  are  reemerging  and 
becoming  more  difficult  to  treat  because  of  increased  vulnerability  and  drug  resistance.  New 
infectious  diseases  are  emerging  (human  immunodeficiency  virus  [HIV],  severe  acute 
respiratory  syndrome,  avian  influenza).  HIV  prevalence  has  increased  slowly,  although  it 
remains concentrated in high risk groups. 
 
4. 
Immediate attention is required to the slow progress in attaining the health-related MDGs 
and  to  improve  prevention  and  early  curing  of  incapacitating  diseases.  The  large  regional 
disparities point to the need for giving specific attention to deprived regions and to the deprived 
and vulnerable categories of the population (in rural areas and urban slums).  
 
The Philippines has a dual health system of largely tax-financed public health services at 
5. 
national and local levels plus an extensive for-profit and nonprofit private sector that is largely 
financed  from  user  fees.  Social  health  insurance  has  been  introduced  and  is  being  expanded 
gradually as a way of pooling risk, establishing  accreditation, and contracting services. This is 
expected  to  improve  access  for  the  poor  and  vulnerable,  although  the  range  of  reimbursable 
services and access to quality services remain limited.

Main Issues 

B. 
 
13. 
The  current  system  is  fragmented  in  its  organization  and  management,  in  its  services, 
and in financing. In effect, a two-tier system exists: the private sector for the rich (mainly located 
in the cities) and the public system for the poor. Health system funding shows a problematic mix 
that  is  part  national  health  system,  part  social  health  insurance  system,  and  combined  with  a 
halfway  devolved  system  providing  mandates  for  regulating  and  financing  the  sector  to  DOH, 
LGUs,  and  PHIC  (all  of  which  deal  with  the  same  health  service  providers,  both  publicly  and 
privately owned). The public system lacks funding, instruments for stewardship and regulatory 
capacity,  enforcement  and  effective  use  of  existing  regulation,  and  incentives  for  health  care 
providers.  There  are  major  challenges—but  also  opportunities—in 
improving  access, 
affordability, quality, management, and financing of health services.  
 

1. 

Access  

14. 
A 2003 survey identified problems of financial, geographic, and cultural access to health 
care.2 Better  health  services  were  characterized  as  follows  (i)  health  professional  are  reliable, 
(ii) drugs and diagnostic equipment are available, and (iii) the building is clean and people are 
treated with dignity. People equate good staff attitude and cleanliness with quality care, which is 
often seen as lacking in public health services. Availability of free or inexpensive (generic) drugs 
is  appreciated  but  patients  have  more  confidence  in  branded  drugs. Demand  for  preventive 
health  care  is  low. Use  of  traditional  healers  is still  widely  practiced  before  and  after  visiting  a 
modern clinic.  
 
According to the same survey (footnote 2), facility-based deliveries increased from 34% 
15. 
in the 5 years preceding 1998 to 38% in the 5 years preceding the 2003 survey. Sixty percent of 
births  in  the  5  years  before  the  2003  survey  were  assisted by  health  professionals (34%  by  a 
doctor and 26% by a midwife or a nurse) compared with 56% in the 5 years preceding the 1998 
survey (footnote 2). WHO recommends that every delivery should take place in a well-equipped 
health  facility,  and  be  led  by  a  health  professional.  Regional  variation  ranges  from  fewer  than 
40%  of  births  assisted  by  health  professionals  in  Bicol,  Caraga,  and  Autonomous  Region  in 
Muslim Mindanao to over 80% in Central Luzon and the National Capital Region. Importantly, in 
38% of cases of maternal death there was no medical attendance.  
 
16. 
The use of services is slightly higher for public health services and quite evenly spread 
across the country, although slightly higher in urban areas. A major problem is the bypassing of 
public facilities or going straight to tertiary care facilities when primary or secondary care would 
have  been  sufficient.  This  is  due  to  the  perceived  low  quality  of  care  and  unavailability  of 
medicines.  Many  government  hospitals  have  inadequate  budgetary  support  and  managerial 
autonomy  after  devolution.  Private  services  are  perceived  to  offer  better  quality  care,  to  be 
similar in terms of access, but to be more costly. Public health services are more often used by 
the poor who cannot afford private services. 
 
17. 
District  hospitals,  although  classified  as  secondary  hospitals,  are  often  structured  as 
primary care hospitals (under 50 beds), and they offer limited specialist and diagnostic services. 
Provincial hospitals are structured as secondary care hospitals, have specialist and diagnostic 
services  with  limited  capacity,  but  are  located  in  larger  towns  and  cities.  Nongovernment 
secondary  care  hospitals  are  mostly  located  in  urban  areas.  Most  hospital  beds  are  in  urban 
tertiary  hospitals.  The  current  PHIC-operated  accreditation  system  creates  an  incentive  for

2. 

Affordability 

18. 
Some 33% of Filipinos are classified as poor, while 20% of the urban population and 47% 
of the rural people are poor. Almost half of health care costs are paid out-of-pocket, while PHIC 
contributes only 10% of these costs.3 Fees for services may deter the poor from seeking health 
services at all or may cause greater poverty, indebtedness, and loss of land. The poor will often 
not  be  able  to  afford  basic  health  care  (and  therefore  often  delay  care  until  it  is  too  late,  which 
particularly  affects  children).  Also,  the  nonpoor  may  find  it  difficult  to  pay  for  catastrophic  and 
chronic  care.  If  not  deferring  treatment,  families  use  other  strategies  to  meet  their  health  care 
needs,  including  self-medication,  sharing  medicine,  and  going  into  debt  for  severe  illnesses 
(including for terminal illnesses of the elderly). Given high levels of unemployment and prevailing 
social structures, income generators may also end up in poverty while caring for dependents.  
 
19. 
Drugs constitute half of health expenditures. Except for the indigent, PHIC does not yet 
offer  reimbursement  for  outpatient  drugs.  The  absence  of  such  reimbursement  may  be  cause 
for  unnecessary  hospital  admission,  not  only  because  of  forgone  prevention  opportunities  but 
also simply to obtain medicines inside a hospital that are unaffordable to patients in outpatient 
care. DOH is addressing this issue by gradually expanding access to simple drugstores via its 
system of botika ng barangay (community-managed drug outlets), which offer a limited variety 
of  essential  drugs  at  low  prices  procured  via  international  competitive  bidding  by  Philippine 
International Trading Corporation.

Management 

25. 
On the national and LGU levels, the country lacks adequate instruments for stewardship 
and insufficient regulatory and enforcement capacity for planning and distribution of health care 
resources,  for  provider  performance  review,  and  for  quality  assurance.  As  a  consequence,

develop  provincial  investment  plans  for  health.  These  plans  (for  which  financing  is  essential) 
should facilitate targeted investments and better access to upgraded health care facilities.  
 
26.

the  facilities  are  run  not  by  trained  management  specialists  but  by  clinical  staff.  In  addition,

results  in  poor  drug  management  and  dangerous  stock-outs.  The  system  inefficiencies  have 
been costly. Alternative options need to be explored, including to strengthen in-house capacity 
for  management  or  outsourcing  to  third  parties.  A  DOH  initiative  to  train  health  managers 
contributes to solving the problems, but it is on a too-small scale.

devolution  has  made  it  difficult  to  implement  national  policies  and  health  objectives.  DOH  has 
only  advisory  power  vis-à-vis  the  LGUs  on  some  of  the  issues  critical  for  the  proposed  DBP 
health  care  investment  program.  The  LGUs  have  limited  capacity  and  means  for  adequately 
directing the health sector in their areas and for managing the health care facilities under their 
responsibility. Implementing rationalization of health services in the provinces has proven to be 
difficult, despite the support of DOH. LGUs do not always take into account the capacity of the 
private  sector  and  sometimes  do  not  have  data  on  its  distribution,  function,  and  capacity.

Financing  

29. 
About  3.4%  of  gross  domestic  product  is  spent  on  health  (footnote  3).  That  is  low 
compared with the WHO-advised level of 5% for middle-income countries. The larger part of this 
is  spent  on  tertiary  hospital  services.  The  public  tends  to  bypass  lower  facilities  and  access 
tertiary hospitals even for relatively minor problems. The funding arrangements make it difficult 
to regulate the sector by financial means.  
 
30. 
The country has not made a clear choice for either a budget-funded system, eventually 
to be combined with devolution to LGUs, or an insurance-funded system. Mandated pooling of 
funding  and,  subsequently,  a  single-payer  system  do  not  exist.  This  leads  to  fragmentation  of 
both funding and of care, with subsequent administrative and health care inefficiencies. In such 
a fragmented system, none of the government bodies has sufficient regulatory enforcement or 
financial clout to effectively and efficiently govern the system of public and private providers.  
 
Health care is financed by multiple payers and from at least four different main sources: 
31. 
the  national  budget  (16.7%),  the  LGU  budget  (17.5%),  PHIC  (9.5%),  private  insurers,  and 
private out-of-pocket spending at the point of service (48%).  
 
PHIC  funding  is  also  out  of  balance.  While  the  national  health  insurance  system  is 
32. 
compulsory, it effectively coverings only 75% of the population. It has difficulty enrolling the rich, 
such as the self-employed like lawyers and doctors. PHIC tries to expand the enrollment of the 
poor  via  an  LGU-sponsored  program  for  the  indigent.  Formal  employers  and  employees  pay 
income-dependent  contributions,  while  the  informal  sector  pays  a  flat  and  comparably  low 
premium of P1,200 per year to allow the poor to become members of PHIC. Overseas foreign 
workers and their dependents in the Philippines pay an even lower premium of P900 per year. 
 
As  there  is  little  or  no  coordination  between  these  various  sources  of  funding,  there 
33.

providers.  Assessing  the  performance  of  health  care  providers  is  difficult—and  scarcely

34.  Moreover, current payment systems are not well tuned to act as incentives for providing 
care  efficiently  and  at  the  right level  of  care.  The  current fee-for-service  system  for specialists 
encourages specialists to eagerly accept and keep patients and then to do as much as possible 
for  each.  Meanwhile,  the  existing  financing  for  public  primary  health  care  is  no  incentive  for 
doing as much as possible at the primary care level. The absence of a referral system further 
contributes to the inappropriate use of care at an unnecessarily high level. Not all LGUs appear 
to transfer their agreed health budgets in full, or they pass the PHIC-received payments to the 
providers, thus sometimes prompting the staff (like midwives) to leave the public sector and go 
into private practice. PHIC has no insight into the funds flows of LGUs, and there is no external 
audit or accountability of the LGUs (e.g., as regards their fully transferring 70% of the capitation 
for enrolling indigent people in PHIC). 
 
35. 
The  current  reimbursement  in  PHIC’s  fee-for-service  system  leaves  little  possibility  for 
controlling the volume of services and leads to over-servicing by the health care providers. This 
may eventually be to the detriment of patients’ health, and it will certainly lead to draining away 
scarce  resources.  Legally  and  practically,  therefore,  PHIC  has  no  effective  relationship  with 
(especially)  the  private  providers  other  than  through  the  accreditation  system  to  influence  the 
quality  of  care.  It  is  considering,  however,  to  introduce  a  contracting  system  together  with  a 
case-based payment system, but only for inpatient care. If properly monitored and if the case-
based payment system is capped by a maximum budget per hospital, this may alleviate some of 
the counterproductive incentives and supply-induced demand.

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  poverty  reduction  strategy  states  "Poverty  is  a  deprivation  of  essential  assets  and 
opportunities to which every human is entitled. Everyone should have access to basic education and primary health services." 
The Philippine country poverty assessment  states "Health status affects a person’s ability to go to school, to obtain  work and 
generate income, and to generally participate in society." The poverty assessment notes that access to quality health care is a 
pressing poverty issue, particularly for maternal and child health care and treatment of communicable disease, although health 
spending is well below international standards and on a downward trend. The Philippines country strategy and program update 
2005–2007 calls for a refined focus to achieve more rapid poverty reduction and progress toward the Millennium Development 
Goals (MDGs). While fiscal constraints persist, it adds direct support for the MDGs will be coursed through off-budget financing. 
The Philippines’ progress toward achieving the MDGs has been uneven. While the country appears to be on track for achieving 
most  MDG  goals,  the  goals  are  not  yet  met.  The  most  recent  MDG  progress  reporta  calls  for  accelerating  implementation  of 
basic education and health care reforms, strengthening the capacity of local government units (LGUs) to provide basic services, 
and    generating  and  mobilizing  resources  for  MDG-related  programs.  The  proposed  loan  has  been  designed  to  support 
achievement  of  the  health-related  MDGs  without  burdening  fiscal  capacity  and  while  mobilizing  additional  resources  by 
leveraging private participation.

1. Key Issues  
Philippine  progress  in  reducing  poverty  has  been  uneven,  and  the  2007  MDG  report  on  the  probability  of  achieving  the 
47 indicators  associated  with  the  eight  MDG  goals  cautions  that  a  high  probability  is  not  a  guarantee  of  achievement.  The 
Project focuses on health MDGs: Goal 4 to reduce under-five and infant mortality; Goal 5 to improve maternal health; and Goal 
6 to combat HIV/AIDS, malaria, and other diseases. The Philippines’ performance has been mixed. The probability is high for 
achieving  indicators  4.1  on  under-five  mortality,  4.2  on  infant  mortality,  and  6.6  on  malaria.  The  probability  is  medium  for 
achieving indicator 6.9 on the prevalence of tuberculosis. The probability is low for achieving indicator 4.3 on child immunization, 
indicator 5.1 on maternal mortality, indicator 5.2 on the proportion of births attended by a skilled birth attendant, indicator 5.3 on 
the use of contraceptives, and indicator 6.9 on deaths from tuberculosis.b 
 
The Project was designed to support implementation of the Government’s agenda in health sector reform toward achieving the 
MDGs.  The  Department  of  Health  (DOH)  Fourmula  One  for  Health  (F1)  reforms  enhance  access  to  primary  medical  care 
services,  strengthen  effective  access  to  secondary  referral  care  services,  promote  partnership  between  the  public  and 
nongovernment sectors to address gaps in the public system, and promote innovative strategies for health system performance 
and efficiency gain. 
 
The  Kapit  Bisig  Laban  sa  Kahirapan  (KALAHI),  which  means  linking  arms  against  poverty,  was  launched  in  2001  as  the 
Government’s strategic framework for poverty reduction The framework has five components: (i) accelerated asset reform, (ii) 
improved  access  to  human  development  services,  (iii)  provision  of  employment  and  livelihood  opportunities,  (iv)  security  from 
violence and social protection, and (v) institutionalized and strengthened participation. The KALAHI approach bringing together 
all levels of government, the private sector, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and the target groups (farmers and landless 
rural  workers,  fisherfolk,  informal  sector  workers,  indigenous  peoples,  women,  children,  youth,  the  elderly,  and  victims  of 
calamities). KALAHI-CIDSS (Comprehensive and Integrated Delivery of Social Services) is the Government’s flagship program 
for improving access to human development services using a community-driven development approach and providing funding 
for microfinance for livelihood development and basic infrastructure investment, including in barangay health stations. 
 
The  Project  links  to  the  KALAHI  strategy  in  several  ways.  The  aim  is  to  reduce  poverty  through  achieving  the  health-related 
MDGs  by  improving  access  to  basic  health  services  (component  i)  while  creating  employment  and  livelihood  opportunities 
(component iii) with the participation of government, the private sector, and NGOs. The Project provides an innovative package 
of  health  industry  financial  services  enabling  health  service  sector  professionals  to  establish  or  expand  their  services.  A 
significant portion of the investment will be for such micro-health enterprises as birthing homes and distributors and retailers of 
generic drugs, as well as for such small health enterprises as rural health units, primary care hospitals, or upgrading secondary 
care  hospitals.  Local  governments  with  limited  fiscal  capacity  will  gain  access  to  off-budget  means  (through  a  development 
financial  intermediary)  to  borrow  for  their  health  investment  needs.  The  Project  encourages  public–private  partnerships  by 
enabling the public sector to guarantee a minimum level of income to private investors, thus resulting in increased provision of 
health care services at a lower cost to the government. DOH and the Philippines Health Insurance Company (PHIC) are also 
partners  in  the  Project  by  facilitating  accreditation  and  expansion  plus  timely  reimbursements  of  health  care  delivery  costs.

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
The Project’s ultimate beneficiaries are women, children, indigents and the ill, and families.  
 
Women bear multiple costs of inadequate access to health care in their reproductive and child-rearing roles. Maternal mortality 
is intractably high. Fifty-five percent of all Filipino women deliver at home. Yet one of the major interventions to reduce maternal 
mortality  and  improve  neonatal  survival  is  for  a  woman  to  deliver  at  a  properly  equipped  health  facility  attended  by  a 
professional. Location plays a large role in determining place of delivery. In rural areas, 43% of women in the highest income 
quintile deliver at home, while among their better-served urban counterparts only 17% of women in the highest income quintile 
deliver at home.c The most frequently cited reason for women delivering at home is cost. Hospital delivery is expensive. Public 
programs  provide  free  antenatal  care  for  poor  women  but  not  the  cost  of  delivery.  Facilitating  PHIC  accreditation  of  service 
providers,  including  midwives,  reduces  patient  out-of-pocket  costs  and  brings  quality  obstetric  care  closer  to  home  at  a 
significantly lower cost. 
 
The  leading  causes  of  death  among  children  under  5  years  old  are  largely  preventable:  pneumonia,  diarrhea,  and  measles. 
Poor  access  to  PHC  results  in  underutilization,  thus  transforming  manageable  illnesses  into  catastrophic  events.  The  rural 
health  units  (RHUs)  are  often  understaffed  and  essential  drugs  stocked-out,  thus  constraining  their  support  to  the  barangay 
health station (BHS) front-line care and public outreach programs. RHUs and BHSs jointly provide 50% of all outpatient care. 
Upgrading  rural  health  units  performance  is  key  to  effectively  delivering  PHC  and  reducing  the  leading  causes  of  under-5 
mortality. 
 
The  same  proportion  of  poor  and  nonpoor—many  of  whom  are  near-poor—self-medicate  when  ill.  The  most  significant 
difference between poor and nonpoor is in the choice of service provider; the public sector provides more than half of all care for 
the  poor  and  nonpoor.d  The  private  sector  also  serves  a  surprisingly  large  proportion  of  the  poor.  In  Metro  Manila,  the  poor 
almost exclusively use the public  health  system for outpatient care, and 60% make use of city  and barangay health services. 
The public sector serves about 60% of the nonpoor. Outside of Metro Manila, 75% of the poor utilize the public health system for 
outpatient  services  compared  to  about  60%  of  the  non-poor.  The  private  sector  provides  the  balance.  While  private  sector 
medical care is sometimes viewed as beyond the reach of the poor, it is in fact an important partner to government in providing 
health care services to the poor.
